publicwhip.spmotion: *S2M-1837# Karen Whitefield: Diabetes in Scotland—That the Parliament notes the rising numbers of people with diabetes in Scotland as evidenced in the recent report from Diabetes UK Scotland, Diabetes in Scotland and the UK 2004, which shows that there are 148,000 people in Scotland diagnosed with diabetes, a rise of 28,000 since 1996; is concerned that at least 65,000 people in Scotland are undiagnosed, as highlighted in the report, and that this number is rising year-on-year; recognises that diabetes is associated with chronic ill-health, disability and premature mortality and that long-term complications, including heart disease, strokes, blindness, kidney disease and amputations, make the greatest contribution to the costs of diabetes care, and believes that many of these long-term effects could be avoided with earlier identification and more effective treatment.

S2M-1837# Karen Whitefield: Diabetes in Scotland—That the Parliament notes the rising numbers of people with diabetes in Scotland as evidenced in the recent report from Diabetes UK Scotland, Diabetes in Scotland and the UK 2004, which shows that there are 148,000 people in Scotland diagnosed with diabetes, a rise of 28,000 since 1996; is concerned that at least 65,000 people in Scotland are undiagnosed, as highlighted in the report, and that this number is rising year-on-year; recognises that diabetes is associated with chronic ill-health, disability and premature mortality and that long-term complications, including heart disease, strokes, blindness, kidney disease and amputations, make the greatest contribution to the costs of diabetes care, and believes that many of these long-term effects could be avoided with earlier identification and more effective treatment. Supported by: Stewart Stevenson*
S2M-1837# Diabetes in Scotland (lodged on 7 October 2004) Mary Scanlon*, Carolyn Leckie*, Frances Curran*
S2M-1837# Diabetes in Scotland (lodged on 7 October 2004) Robert Brown*
S2M-1837# Diabetes in Scotland (lodged on 7 October 2004) Michael Matheson*, Scott Barrie*
S2M-1837# Diabetes in Scotland (lodged on 7 October 2004) Mr David Davidson*, Donald Gorrie*

S2M-1837# Diabetes in Scotland (lodged on 7 October 2004) Mike Pringle*, Elaine Smith*, Mr Alasdair Morrison*, Jackie Baillie*, Bill Butler*, Michael McMahon*, Eleanor Scott*, Linda Fabiani*, Fergus Ewing*, Mrs Nanette Milne*, Marlyn Glen*, Bruce Crawford*, Mr Bruce McFee*, Cathie Craigie*, Helen Eadie*, Tricia Marwick*, Mr Kenneth Macintosh*, Brian Adam*, Ms Rosemary Byrne*, Kate Maclean*, Margaret Jamieson*, Christine Grahame*, Tommy Sheridan*
S2M-1837# Diabetes in Scotland (lodged on 7 October 2004) Rosie Kane*, Phil Gallie*, Mr Jamie Stone*, Janis Hughes*, Pauline McNeill*, Paul Martin*
S2M-1837# Diabetes in Scotland (lodged on 7 October 2004) Marilyn Livingstone*
S2M-1837# Diabetes in Scotland (lodged on 7 October 2004) Christine May*, Trish Godman*, Susan Deacon*, Dr Elaine Murray*
S2M-1837# Diabetes in Scotland (lodged on 7 October 2004) Dr Jean Turner*
S2M-1837# Diabetes in Scotland (lodged on 7 October 2004) Cathy Peattie*
S2M-1837# Diabetes in Scotland (lodged on 7 October 2004) John Swinburne*

S2M-1837# Karen Whitefield: Diabetes in Scotland—That the Parliament notes the rising numbers of people with diabetes in Scotland as evidenced in the recent report from Diabetes UK Scotland, Diabetes in Scotland and the UK 2004, which shows that there are 148,000 people in Scotland diagnosed with diabetes, a rise of 28,000 since 1996; is concerned that at least 65,000 people in Scotland are undiagnosed, as highlighted in the report, and that this number is rising year-on-year; recognises that diabetes is associated with chronic ill-health, disability and premature mortality and that long-term complications, including heart disease, strokes, blindness, kidney disease and amputations, make the greatest contribution to the costs of diabetes care, and believes that many of these long-term effects could be avoided with earlier identification and more effective treatment. Supported by: Stewart Stevenson, Mary Scanlon, Carolyn Leckie, Frances Curran, Sarah Boyack, Robert Brown, Michael Matheson, Scott Barrie, Mr David Davidson, Donald Gorrie, Mike Pringle, Elaine Smith, Mr Alasdair Morrison, Jackie Baillie, Bill Butler, Michael McMahon, Eleanor Scott, Linda Fabiani, Fergus Ewing, Mrs Nanette Milne, Marlyn Glen, Bruce Crawford, Mr Bruce McFee, Cathie Craigie, Helen Eadie, Tricia Marwick, Mr Kenneth Macintosh, Brian Adam, Ms Rosemary Byrne, Kate Maclean, Margaret Jamieson, Christine Grahame, Tommy Sheridan, Rosie Kane, Phil Gallie, Mr Jamie Stone, Janis Hughes, Pauline McNeill, Paul Martin, Marilyn Livingstone, Christine May, Trish Godman, Susan Deacon, Dr Elaine Murray, Dr Jean Turner, Cathy Peattie, John Swinburne, John Scott*
S2M-1837# Diabetes in Scotland (lodged on 7 October 2004) Mr Stewart Maxwell*
S2M-1837# Diabetes in Scotland (lodged on 7 October 2004) Mike Rumbles*
